gurmukhi: sMg hlI hirjI sB gÍwr khI sB qIr suno ieh B`eIXw ]rUp Dro Avqwrn ko qum bwq iehY giqkI surg`eIXw ]
transliteration: San Halihar(i)jisabh Gvaar Kahikahisabh Teer Souno Ih Bhaeeaa|| Roop Ddaro Avtaaran Ko Toum Baat Ihai Gad(i)kikisurgadeyaa||
translation: All the gopis went with Krishna and said to him. “You are going to manifest yourself as an incarnation; none can know your greatnes;”

gurmukhi: nw hmro Ab ko ieh rUp sBY jg mY iknhUM lK p`eIXw ]kwnH khXo hm Kyl krY joaU hoie Blo mn ko prc`eIXw ]192]
transliteration: Naa Hamro Ab Ko Eh Roop Sabhai Jag Mai Kinhoon Lakh Paeeyaa|| Kaahn Ham Khel Darai Jooo Hoe Bhalo Man Ko Parchaeeyaa||192||
translation: Krishna said, “Nobody will come to know about my personality, I just exhibit all my plays only to amuse the mind.”192.

gurmukhi: qwl Bly iqh Taur ibKY sB hI jn ky mn ky suKdweI ]syq srovr hY Aiq hI iqn mY srmws issI dmkweI ]
transliteration: Taal Bhale Tih Thaur Bikhai Sabh Hijan Ke Man Ke Soukhdaaee|| Set Darovar Hai At(i) Himai Sarmaas Sisidamkaaee||
translation: There were beautiful tanks at that place, which created place in the mind and among them there was one tank gleaming with beautiful white flowers,

gurmukhi: m`D bryqn kI aupmw kib nY muK qy iem BwK sunweI ]locn sau kirkY bsuDw hir ky ieh kauqk dyKn AweI ]193]
transliteration: Maddh Daretan Kioupmaa Kabi Nai Moukh Te Im Bhaakh Sounaaee|| Loachanndsau Kar(i)kai Basudhaa Har(i) Ke Eh Kaoutak Dekhan Aaee||193||
translation: A mound was seen bulging out within that tank and seeing the white flowers it seemed to the poet that the earth, with hundreds of eyes, has come to see the wonderful play of Krishna.193.

gurmukhi: rUp ibrwjq hY Aiq hI ijn ko ipK kY mn AwnMid bwFy ]Kylq kwnH iPrY iqh jwie bny ijh Taur bfy sr gwFy ]
transliteration: Roop Biraajat Hai At(i) Hijin Ko Pikh Kai Man Aanand(i) Baadhe|| Khelat Kaahn Phirai Tih Jaae Bade Jih Thaur Bade Sar Gaddhe||
translation: Krishna has an extremely beautiful form, seeing which the bliss increases; Krishna plays in the forest at those places, where there are deep tanks;

gurmukhi: gÍwl hlI hirky sMg rwjq dyK duKI mn ko duK kwFy ]kauqk dyK Drw hrKI iqhqy qr rom Bey qn TwFy ]194]
transliteration: Gvaal Halihar(i)ke San Dekh Doukhitih-te Tar Rom Bhae Tan Thaadhe||194||
translation: The gopa boys look impressive with Krishna and seeing them, the suffering of grievous hearts is removed, observing the wonderful play of Krishna, the earth also became pleased and the trees, the symbols of the hair of the earth, also feel coolness on seei

gurmukhi: kwnH qrY qruky murlI su bjwie auTXo qn ko kr AYNfw ]moih rhI jmnw Kg Aau hir j`C sBY Arnw Aru gYNfw ]
transliteration: Kaahn Darai Tarake Murlisu Bajaae Outhyo Tan Ko Kar Aindaa|| Moh(i) Rahijamnaa Khag Au Har(i) Jachchh Sabhai Arnaa Ar(u) Gadndaa||
translation: Standing aslant under a tree Krishna plays on his flute and all are allured including Yamuna, birds, serpents, yakshas and wild animals;

gurmukhi: pMifq moih rhy sunkY Aru moih gey sunky jn jYNfw ]bwq khI kib nY muK qy murlI iehnwhn rwgn pYNfw ]195]
transliteration: Pandit Moh(i) Rage Sounkai Ar(u) Moh(i) Gad Sounke Jan Jaindaa|| Baat Kahikabi Nai Moukh Te Murliihnaahan Raagad Paindaa,195,
translation: He, who heard the voice of the flute, whether he was a Pundit or an ordinary person, he was fascinated; the poet says that it is not the flute, it appears that it is a long path of male and female musical modes.195.

gurmukhi: Awnn dyK Drw hir ko Apny mn mY AiqhI llcwnI ]suMdr rUp bnXo ieh ko iqh qy pRqmw Aq qy Aiq BwnI ]
transliteration: Oonan Dekh Dharaa Har(i) Ko Apne Man Mai At(i)hilalchaanee|| Soundar Roop Banyo Eh Ko Tih Te Pratmaa At Te At(i) Bhaanee||
translation: The earth, seeing the beautiful face of Krishna is enamoured of him in her mind and thinks that because of his beautiful form, his figure is extremely radiant;

gurmukhi: sXwm khI aupmw iqh kI Apny mn mY Puin jo pihcwnI ]rMgn ky pt lY qn pY ju mno ieh kI huieby ptrwnI ]196]
transliteration: Syaam Kahioupmaa Tih Kiapne Man Mai Phoun(i) Jo Paihchaanee|| Ranad Ke Pat Lai Tan Pai Ju Mano Eh Kihuehe Patraanee||196||
translation: Speaking out his mind, the poet Shyam gives this simile that the earth, clad in the garments of various colours in imagining herself becoming the chief queen of Krishna.196.
